data.title: Buster Davis scores
data.text:
Buster Davis (1918-1987), educated at Princeton University, was an active Musical Director and Vocal Arranger for Broadway theatrical productions from the 1940s through the 1980s. Buster Davis arranged and directed numerous productions composed by Jule Styne, including Funny Girland Bells Are Ringing. His musical Doctor Jazz, for which he wrote the music and lyrics and served as Musical Director and Vocal Arranger, had a short run on Broadway at the Winter Garden Theatre in 1975.

Mr. Davis also wrote special material for many television shows, including the Bell Telephone Hour featuring the Buster Davis Singers and the Art Carney Show. In his later years Buster Davis taught courses on The American Musical Theatre and Vocal Arranging, where he shared his personal and musical knowledge of songwriters such as Jerome Kern, Cole Porter, Richard Rodgers, Jule Styne, Vincent Youmans, and many others.

Sources:

“Davis, Buster.” ASCAP Biographical Dictionary. 4th ed. New York: Jacques Cattell Press, 1980.

“Buster Davis.” The Internet Broadway Database. (accessed 27 July 2004),

The bulk of the collection consists of scores of theatrical works and works written for television that Buster Davis wrote, arranged, directed, and/or studied. Also included are individual songs written by Mr. Davis and others, a group of scores composed and arranged for television broadcast, holograph manuscript lecture notes, and other writings. There is very little material in the collection documenting Buster Davis’s personal life.

The Buster Davis scores are arranged in three series:

5 folders

This series presents very limited biographical information, financial receipts, press clippings, and correspondence.

14 boxes

This series is the bulk of the collection, and consists of scores of theatrical works, songs, and works composed or arranged for television broadcast.

This series consists of lecture notes for the classes taught by Buster Davis at Santa Barbara (CA) Community College, and a limited number of other writings, including one chapter of Davis's unpublished autobiography.
